body.p: Welcome to the new gentoo.org! Yes, we finally have news on the site; I hope you like the new look and functionality. Now that we have a news page, we can keep everyone up-to-date with the latest Gentoo Linux developments much more easily.

Right now, the XML component of the news system is complete, and Thread (dev-wiki coder) is working on a news database backend. When finished, you'll be able to post comments relating to the news items. Should be pretty neat.

I'm sure that you've also noticed the recent addition of advertising to the site. The purpose of these ads is (as you might guess) to help offset costs involved with Gentoo Linux development. I should also mention that I actually use and have very high opinions of all the products that you see advertised here. Both cvs.gentoo.org and inventor.gentoo.org use Crucial RAM; I (and the Gentoo Linux development team) rely on it daily.

And while you may be surprised to see an ad for an online auto loan company on gentoo.org, I absolutely love PeopleFirst.com. Thanks to PeopleFirst, I was able to get a car loan with an APR 2% lower than what I could get from local credit unions, saving me hundreds of dollars. And they have always been great to deal with, from the moment I first contacted them. If you have any questions about our advertisers, please feel free to email me or chat with me on #gentoo. I want you (and myself!) to feel comfortable with the advertising on the site, so I will only advertise top-quality products.

Special thanks to Thread for his work on the dev-wiki and his current work on the News database backend, and much thanks to Jano for providing us with the cool stickman graphic that you see on the left. :)
I tend to get a lot of questions about our next release of Gentoo Linux, so why not kick off our news page with a in-depth Gentoo Linux 1.0_rc6 status update?

Release candidate 6 is coming along nicely. Currently, we have the new dependency-based initscripts completed and working. I wasn't really satisfied with any of the current dependency-based init systems available, so we implemented our own system using a bit of bash wizardry. We designed our new dep-based scripts to work with the standard /sbin/init, so no newfangled version of init is required. These new scripts are really fast and really slick. We are also now using a brand new modules.conf generation system straight from Debian, which seems to be working quite well.

I just released the first version of the rc6 build image last night (13 Aug). For those who don't know, a build image is a minimal chrootable self-building environment used as the foundation for building a complete Gentoo Linux release. You can't actually boot it, and right now, it's only for developers who are working to get their packages Gentoo Linux 1.0_rc6-ready, but if you'd like to play with it, you can download it here. This new build image has lots of improvements over rc5. We now install kernel headers into /usr/include/linux and /usr/include/asm directly, rather than using symlinks to point to the appropriate directories in /usr/src/linux. This is a good thing; it's recommended that you keep the set of kernel headers that you used to build glibc, and we're doing that now. Also, vim is out and nano (a lean and mean pico clone) is in as the default build image editor. The new dependency-based initscripts are in. Our glibc has been tweaked so that rc6 will be IBM, Sun and Blackdown Java-compatible. Not only that, but the current rc6 build image is 3.8Mb smaller (13.1Mb) than our rc5 build image (16.9Mb)! And you can expect it to shrink by at least another Megabyte when we replace nano with e3, an editor written in assembly that supports vi, emacs and pico keybindings. Fun, fun, fun!
